children.subject:
FYI, you'll get better advice if you answer the following questions:
1) What year are you? Are you a junior transfer? (And do you have any major constraints on your class scheduling like a second major or trying to graduate early)
2) what classes have you taken previously? And were those semesters too much, just right, or easy?
3) what's your long term goal? Software Engineering Job? Web Dev? AI? A PhD?

I disagree. 61B doesn't go deep enough into algorithms (though it provides a sufficient basis to build off of). 170 is overkill in most cases, but its good to get comfortable on harder problems so the easier ones don't seem so intimidating. 61C is very helpful for interviews. Knowing C programming (how to manage your own memory), understanding how programs are structured (stack, heap etc), parallelism and cache-minded programming is very helpful for many types of interviews.
Different anon who's had a decent amount of experience interviewing. I've never used any 61c knowledge for interviews.

Idk how much recruiting experience you have, but you don't need 170/61c for recruiting. Honestly. The very few DP questions I've ever been asked have boiled down to just some form of memoization + almost ever time the alg I use is just some sort of graph traversal or merge interval stuff. 

If you know your data structures, you know how to interview, and you know how to write clean code, you're fine. 

Don't take 170/61c if recruiting is your motivating factor.

history.content:
I would recommend taking 61C + 170, but to take caution with that workload because 61C is heavily project-based and 170 has weekly problem sets. Taking 61C early will open up more CS upper division courses you can take in the future (161, 162, 168). In my opinion, 170 greatly helps with the recruiting process. While dynamic programming is important, the more important take away from 170 is just how to approach and break down problems (problem solving). This is generally a useful skill in CS for classes and for interviews.

Since you're aiming to be a Software Engineer, I think you can hold off on 16B as it's nothing more than a graduation requirement that's not as beneficial at the current stage in your CS career.

children.subject: Thanks for the responses guys.  But I've heard about 61c + 170 being a nasty combo.  Thoughts?

history.content:
I would like to start 170 and 61c for recruiting in the Spring, but on the other hand I would like to complete 16B to complete my lower divisions.  I don't know what to do, because I don't have much time left and I would love to hear about any responses you all have between these two schedules.

Currently: Junior, graduation 2020

Goal: Software Engineering, but anything is fine because all topics of CS are sick

Favorite thing so far about CS classes: 61A/61B projects, probability, learning math, ultimately making things out of scratch is challenging but fun and rewarding,

TLDR I really just like learning

Thank you!

Taken EE16A, 61A,

Taking 61B, 70 concurrently, pretty doable so far
history.subject: 61C + 170 vs 61C + 16B + 160/188?
